title: Gene Pitney - Sings The Great Songs Of Our Times (1965) + Nobody

info.txt (which is simply these notes included in the torrent)

First biography paragraph from All Music (by Richie Unterberger):

One of the most interesting and difficult-to-categorize singers in '60s pop, Gene Pitney had a long run of hits distinguished by his pained, one-of-a-kind melodramatic wail. Pitney is sometimes characterized (or dismissed) as a shallow teen idol-type prone to operatic ballads. It's true that some of his biggest hits -- "Town Without Pity," "Only Love Can Break a Heart," "I'm Gonna Be Strong," "It Hurts to Be in Love," and "Twenty Four Hours From Tulsa" -- are archetypes of adolescent or just-post-adolescent agony, characterized by longing and not a little self-pity.

Read all of the bio at: <a href=" http://www.allmusic.com/artist/gene-pitney-p5148/biography" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW"> http://www.allmusic.com/artist/gene-pitney-p5148/biography</a>

All Music Album Reviews:

2 for 1
AMG Review
by Cub Koda

Two albums on one CD, this features straight-up reissues of Pitney's two Musicor albums with three bonus tracks tacked on at the end. Sings the Great Songs of Our Time is a U.K. retitle of Pitney's American Looking Through the Eyes of Love album and finds Pitney covering several old-time standards like "Misty," "Unchained Melody," and "All the Way" with various levels of success. The Nobody Needs Your Love album features the hit "Backstage" along with Randy Newman's title song. The three bonus tracks are both sides of his 1966 mid-charter, "Princess in Rags" and "Amore Mio" and the U.K. flip side of "Backstage," "In Love Again." Not essentially Pitney, but a nice set with its moments.

Taken from: <a href=" http://www.allmusic.com/album/sings-the-great-songs-of-our-time-nobody-needs-your-love-r258663" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW"> http://www.allmusic.com/album/sings-the-great-songs-of-our-time-nobody-needs-your-love-r258663</a>
